message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest adrenal insufficiency, specifically primary adrenal insufficiency or Addison's disease. The morning serum cortisol test result confirms this. The best next step in this case is to perform an ACTH stimulation test to confirm the diagnosis and determine the degree of adrenal insufficiency. Testing for plasma aldosterone, adrenal imaging, or 21-hydroxylase antibodies is not necessary in this case as they are not relevant to the diagnosis of primary adrenal insufficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including hypotension, hyperpigmentation, and low serum cortisol, suggest adrenal insufficiency. An ACTH stimulation test can confirm the diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency. Plasma aldosterone and adrenal imaging are not necessary to diagnose adrenal insufficiency, and 21-hydroxylase antibodies are more commonly associated with autoimmune adrenalitis, which is a less common cause of adrenal insufficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest adrenal insufficiency, as indicated by the low morning serum cortisol test. The most appropriate next step would be an ACTH stimulation test to confirm the diagnosis. Plasma aldosterone levels would be helpful if there was suspicion of mineralocorticoid deficiency. Adrenal imaging would be useful if there was suspicion of an adrenal mass or tumor. 21-hydroxylase antibodies would be helpful if there was suspicion of autoimmune adrenal insufficiency.
